response.answer_text: Why Is There No Life On The Moon? Without any atmosphere, or the ability to create one, the moon cannot provide the basic conditions for life to develop. When you stare up into the night sky, it’s hard to miss the brightest object and our closest celestial neighbour – the moon. It has fascinated humans for thousands of years, was worshipped as a god in the past, and has inspired countless generations to wonder whether alien life may be waiting for us on our doorstep. However, with the advent of space travel, our 6 Apollo missions to the moon, and our improved ability to learn about the composition of celestial bodies from Earth, we now know that the moon cannot and never has supported life. The questions, therefore, is why does the moon contain no signs of life? What is the Moon? The moon is our planet’s natural satellite, orbiting Earth every 27.3 days and rotating on its own axis every 27 days. Interestingly enough, this similarity in its rotation and orbit means that the same side of the moon always faces Earth, a phenomenon called synchronous rotation. The moon is roughly 27% the size of the Earth, with a diameter of 3,474 kilometers. There is some debate about how the moon was formed, but the prevailing theory is the giant-impact theory, which argues that in the early days of our planet’s formation, before any life had developed, another planetary body the size of Mars crashed into the young Earth, jettisoning billions of tons of elemental material into the orbit around the planet. There was so much debris that gravity was able to form and pull it together, forming what we know today as the moon. Since that point, the Moon’s orbit has regularized around our planet, so accurately that we base our calendar progression off its changing phases. However, while the moon often feels like another planet, a moon is very different than a planetary body. The most basic different is that a planet orbits a star, whereas a moon orbits a planet. Furthermore, in the case ofEarth and its moon, the composition of the planet is different. At the center of the Earth is a dense core of heavy metals, which creates a magnetic field and a strong gravitational pull, which enables the planet to retain an atmosphere. Without our atmosphere, none of us would be here today, nor would you be reading this article! Does the Moon have an atmosphere? As mentioned above, the moon does not have the same composition as the Earth, and while some of the elements present on the moon are the same, this is likely because of the moon’s formation (the Giant-Impact Theory). In general, this different in composition means that the moon cannot have an atmosphere because it is not geologically active. Without the release or production of gases in the core of a planetary body or moon, an atmosphere would be unable to form – atmospheres don’t happen spontaneously! Furthermore, even if those gases were to be produced or released, the low gravity of the moon would make it difficult to hold onto those molecules. For a molecule to be released into the emptiness of space, they need to exceed the escape velocity of the planet or moon. When the sun strikes these molecules, it energizes them, and if they are moving fast enough to overcome the pull of gravity, they will escape.  In the case of Earth’s moon, any light molecules present there would be immediately energized by the sun, due to Earth’s proximity to our star, and those molecules would escape into the emptiness of space, making the formation of an atmosphere next to impossible. That being said, some heavy molecules are present on the surface of the moon, forming what is commonly known as an exosphere. It is extremely low in density, trillions of times less concentrated than the atmospheric molecules on Earth, but heavy molecules can be found bouncing around the surface of the moon. This is far different than an atmosphere, but there are some molecules found on our orbiting neighbor. Is life impossible on the Moon? Without the presence of an atmosphere, there is no chance for the formation of more complex molecules that are required for life (as we know it). When astronomers peer at distant exoplanets and moons, they are primarily searching for signs of water, or the possibility that water once existed there. Our understanding of life is Earth-centric, and we know that water was integral in the development of life here. On the Moon, based on the history of its formation, its lack of an atmosphere and its classification as a “dead” rock, there is no feasible way for life to develop and prosper on the moon. This is not to say that life cannot survive on the moon, as many science fiction fans are hoping. Our technological advancements mean that we may someday be able to colonize the moon, although recent decades have seen our attention shift to the possibility of establishing a colony on Mars.  The only life that could survive on the moon (or anywhere else in the vacuum of empty space) is the tardigrade. Also known as the water bear, this microscopic organism has been found all over the world and has demonstrated remarkable hardiness to temperature and pressure extremes, as well as surviving without any water. To date, this is the only living organism that has been shown to survive in the vacuum of space, which is a combination of intense pressure, low temperature and high radiation from the sun’s rays. A sample of tardigrades were placed on the outside of a shuttle that orbited the planet for 10 days and then re-entered the atmosphere. Shockingly, more than 60% of the tardigrades survived the experience, which has fascinated scientists ever since, leading to their better understanding of tardigrade’s “stasis” or “dessication” strategy. Going into detail about what makes tardigrades so special is beyond the scope of this article, but when it comes to life potentially surviving on the moon, they are the only creatures who could do so – as far as we know!

Judging by the way the question is phrased I'd say the issue isn't just the zone the planet is in, but the host of other htings you need to make it livable. As Niranjan Daitbankar and Ernest Adams note, there's some basic ingredients you need for life. The moon has a few of them -- for example, there's a little water on the moon and certainly it orbits the sun at the right distance. But to have life you need at a minimum to retain an atmosphere, and you need to be able to have all kinds of complex chemical reactions. As far as anyone can tell water or some other solvent is necessary for those reactions to occur.  Carl Sagan in Cosmos proposed that water isn't the only solvent -- he uses sulfuric acid as an example (sulfuric acid actually stays liquid at a larger temperature range than water). But for any liquids at all to exist you need gas pressure of some kind or other. The moon hasn't got any of that, since its gravity was too weak to retain an atmosphere.  As Mr. Adams notes, a magnetic field is a big help if you want life because solar radiation breaks down complex molecules. That is, there's a whole sea of charged particles (mostly protons) that streams out from the sun. When those particles smack into molecules like DNA they alter them, sometimes breaking them up completely. The Magnetc field around the Earth traps those particles and keeps them away from us. The moon has no field, and this is why solar and ocosmic ray radiation is a hazard for astronauts who go there or plan to be there longer than a few days.  I should add that Mars is in the habitable zone too (barely) and it has no magnetic field to speak of either. That's one reason most of its atmosphere literally blew away.  Now, it is certainly possible to have a metabolism absent liquids. And it's even possible that you could develop a kind of life that involved slow reactions with crystalline structures, made of molecules that are much less vulnerable to radiation and don't need oxygen - perhaps the reactions are powered by the chemical changes wrought by sunlight (one reason the moon has dark spots is "space weathering" where certain metals turn black in the sun). But it wouldn't be anything like what we have on Earth. We might not even recognize it as alive.

Yes, lunar settlement will likely become possible with technology developed in the next 100 years. The main problem specifically on the moon is silicate glass. The moon's entire surface is coated in sharp silicate glass. This is because of the erosion from all the micro-meteorite impacts that have occurred on the moon over the years. There is no atmospheric or water erosion to soften the edges of these glass particles so they are very sharp and very small. When the Apollo astronauts went ro the moon from 1969–1972 they had to keep their spacesuits on while sleeping in the Lunar Lander to prevent breathung in any of the dusty particles their space suits were covered with into their lungs. This meant they were limited to living inside their space suits which severely limited the amount of oxygen, food, and water available to them. Apollo 17, the longest amount of time humans lived on the moon for, was only 75 hours long. This problem coupd be solved by engineering machines that could remove all of the dust particles from astronauts suits before they entered into living structures. The other problems with living on the moon would be building and maintaining habitats that provide for every need of the astronauts for life without being supplied from Earth while protecting them from cosmic radiation. This involves making basically a self contained micro ecosystem on the moon, like on Earth everything would have to be recycled but in a much smaller space, realistically smaller anf much less massive than many buildings on Earth. Rocketing building parts to the moon is so prohibitively expensive that the buildings would have to be made on the moon from the lunar silicate glass, which can be made into a kind of concrete, so the silicate glass being there is also helpful. The lunar habitats would have to be airtight to maintain Earth's atmospheric pressure in the vacuum of space. Even more importantly than this they would have to protect the astronauts from solar radiation. We are protected from solar radiation on Earth because of the Earth's magnetosphere, but this does not reach out to the moon (except very rarely in maybe one spot for a very short period of time). The Apollo missions had to be limited to less than 14 days in part because any exposure much longer than that to radiation outside of Earth's magnetosphere would have been fatal, even with their space suits on. About 3 feet of lunar concrete over the habitat would be necessary to shelter the lunar inhabitants from the radiation. In most places on the moon additional technological advancements would be needed to adequately recycle water and oxygen. On the International Space Station water and oxygen are already recycled, but very inefficiently. Most of the oxygen that the astronauts breathe has to be sent up in rockets. The water recycling is much closer to the efficiency needed but additional improvements are still needed. There is some water ice particularly near the Moon's South Pole that could be used for water and oxygen by converting it into oxygen and hydrogen through electrolysis which requires an electricity supply such as from solar panels. This could also be used to create rocket fuel. Food recyclation would be the most difficult, on Earth it typically takes about 1/3 of an acre of land to feed 1 person, so this would obviously have to be reduced on the moon. There are some hydroponic food habitats on the Earth in developement that are nearly 10 times as efficient as an average acre of crops particularly when combined with insect farming and aquaponics which means structures as little as 2000 sq ft (186 sq m) might feed a person on the moon year round. The plants could also help recycle water and oxygen. Given the high amount of radiation on the moon the plants would have to be grown in the lunar habitat under 3 feet of lunar concrete, which means they would either rely on periscopic windows for sunlight or electric UV lights using electricity from solar panels like is done in the ISS. The lunar night is 2 weeks long so if grown using periscopic windows plants would have to be genetically modified to be compatible with the Moon's diurnal cycles. Batteries could be used to store electric energy during the lunar day to provide it to the lunar habitats during the lunar night. Another one of the problems on the moon is tge extreme temperatures there. Temperatures range from 250 degrees Fahrenheit during the day to -286 degrees Fahrenheit during the night. The Apollo astronauts visited the moon during the lunar morning when the lunar ground was still cold. This mean that the water in the skin of their suits was able to transfer the heat from the sun from the suits so that the astronauts did not overheat. If the sun had set while the Apollo astronauts were on one of their EVAs with the lunar buggies several miles from the Lunar Lander they almist certainly would have died from hypothermia as their space suits did not provide adequate protection from -286 F cold. If astronauts were going to live on the moon even just for a full Lunar day or about 28 Earths they would need to protect themselves from these extreme temperarures. -286 F makes most materials including steels very brittle as you can see from putting things in liquid nitrogen. In my material science engineering class I observed that aluminum retains ductility far better than steel does at these colder temperatures so there are some material options at these colder temperatures but not many. Ultimately astronauts would want to live at least 10 feet (3m) underground where the lunar temperatures are a fairly consistent -30 F (-34 C). This is cold, but not as cold as the conditions scientists and others who live in the interior of Antarctica experience. The lunar habitat would be buried anyway to protect from radiation so this kills two birds with one stone. The lunar habitat would still need to be heated, this could be done using electricity from solar panels which of course would be stored in batteries to be used during the lunar night. The lunar habitat could also be surrounded by a pool of water that retain some of this heat. Finally, the Moon has 1/6 the gravity as the Earth does. No matter how much exercise astronauts have done on the International Space System this has been shown to have increasingly harmful effects on humans in the long run. In order for humans to live on the moon they would need to have artificial gravity, such as that provided by centrifugal acceleration. This has been done before in space for the Gemini 4 orbit in 1967 when two Gemini capsules were tethered to each other so they could slighly spin. Recently it has been done on the ISS with experiments on mice in a centrifuge. The mice lived healthy lives after the experiment without the bone loss and other negative effects of microgravity. On the Moon the lunar habitats would have to be centrifuges at least 10 m in radius and contained underneath a lunar concrete dome with solar panels on the lunar surface providing the electricity to the motors that would keep the centrufuge spinning at the necessary speed for artificial Earth gravity. The astronauts would enter and exit through a rod in the middle of the centrifuge, climbing up to the top above the dome where they would exit onto the lunar surface. Developing and combining all of these technologies will make the first lunar settlement a reality maybe by the end of the 21st century. Once we have settled the moon we can settle pretty much anywhere we want as the moon is not much more habitable than the vacuum of space. Many of these technological innovations will probably be used on the first interstellar spacecraft which could take generations to reach the stars. Clearly it can be seen that lunar settlement is not about the survival of the human species, as Elon Musk argues for Mars colonization, if humans can live on the moon it is very unlikely that anything will happen on the Earth that would make it uninhabitable to us. Living on the moon would be very fun though and it should make the future pretty exciting for us humans.

If a celestial object orbits a star or stars (or even a black hole), it’s called a planet. If the object orbits a planet, then it’s called a moon. There’s no connection between the name and physical properties like size or if it’s habitable or not. Jupiter’s largest moon, Ganymede is larger than Mercury, for example. Definitely larger than Pluto, but poor Pluto is not a planet anymore due to its small size. So there’s nothing preventing moons to have conditions and circumstances that allow life to form. Sci-fi dealt with this kind of situation too. In Isaac Asimov’s Nemesis, it even helps that it’s a moon, not a planet. The planet is too close to a brown dwarf, so it’s tidally locked. Its moon, however, is tidally locked to the planet, so it gets a day-night cycle, preventing one side from heating up and the other to cool down too much.

Maybe. No evidence of life on the Moon has been found so far. However, we can’t rule it out just yet. Just recently, it was reported that Russian cosmonauts on the International Space Station discovered bacteria on the outside of the station. It is unclear whether or not the bacteria was actually living out there, but if bacteria can survive on the outside of an orbiting space station, then the prospects of them surviving inside the Moon isn’t so bad. Generally, bacteria need liquid water at least some of the time to survive. There is no liquid water on the surface of the Moon, but conditions underground should allow for liquid water to exist at least sometimes in certain areas. This would be in areas where the ground temperature rises to above 0 Celsius during the lunar “day.” On the surface, water would evaporate (really sublimate) at that temperature, but underground, it could be trapped and achieve a high enough pressure to form liquid water.
